content: So who's read this new Afghan law? Other than what 'critics' say is in it, nobody, including Afghan parliamentarians, has actually held a copy in their hands. So far it's a giant, and well-attended, 'whoo-whoo' exercise.

content: Another year gone by, and we still haven't found Bin Laden or Al-Zawahiri. Horray for hollow victories!
reply: Another year gone by, and we still haven't found Bin Laden or Al-Zawahiri. Horray for hollow victories!
title: Critics Say Afghan Law ‘Legalizes Rape’

content: Mrmixitup, it's even more hollow than that. 1. We did a Great job knocking out the Taliban and Al Qaeda embedded in the Afghan mountains with Daisy Cutter bombs and their successors. They ran for Pakistan (and presumably some for Iran) and that's where we should have left it. Barry Goldwater's "Bomb Them Back To the Stone Ages" would have saved money, lives, and political fiascos for the USA at least. If the Taliban or Al Qaeda reoccupied the place, we could have knocked them out again just as easily. But instead, we had to "rebuild" Afghanistan's political and economic (what economy? Rugs and Dope?) structure, which lo and behold is about as Stupid a structure as anything in Africa south of the Sahara. 2. Now we're pouring more troops in, and the situation is about where it was before we intervened except we have our "name" on the Government there! Apparently it's all about "name brands". 3. The Taliban, then as now, were almost untouched in Pakistan, to which they fled and from which they returned as Terrorists and Rebels. We refused to seriously use Barry Goldwater's "Bomb Them Back to the Stone Ages" on Western Pakistan because - guess what - we claimed that Pakistan had our "name brand" on its Government. Sound familiar? In the meanwhile, Pakistan gave Iran the knowhow to make its nukes and is behind the Terrorism in India and makes Peace with Pro-Taliban Tribes, agreeing that they have autonomous regions not subject to the Pakistani Government! And Iran has "peacefully" taken over northwest Afghanistan, where there is an enormous pro-Iranian piopulation. 4. And soon we'll be meeting Iran unconditionally for Diplomatic talks at the highest (Presidential) level. Something is seriously wrong with this picture, and it's not in the eye of the beholder. Osher Doctorow

Osher Doctorow It would be a neat trick to "bomb them back into the stone ages." Where exactely are the factories to eliminate? They're already living in the stone age, and that's part of the problem. And you are attacking what would be the main component of ANY succesfull war in Afghanistan. The problem is NOT that we built roads and bridges, the problem is that even though we promised them, we didn't deliver. Instead we took all our resources and put them in Iraq. For every penny we invested in Afghanistan we spent a dollar in Iraq. Instead of picking out men and woman with an interest in defeating hard line fundamentalism, we CHOOSE to support hard line fundamentalists and Dope dealers. Finally, on the question of cooperating with Iran against the common enemy, Al Qaeda, we would be damnd stupid not to take advantage of their self interest, at least on THIS question. Dave

title: Critics Say Afghan Law ‘Legalizes Rape’

content: quote: Karzai bows to international calls to scrap Afghan 'rape' law Afghanistan is to review legislation which the UN says would legalise rape within marriage after a dramatic reversal from the president, Hamid Karzai, who signed the rules into law last month. Karzai has bowed to intense international pressure to scrap the law, described by the UN human rights chief in Afghanistan as "reminiscent of the decrees made by the Taliban regime". It is said to forbid women to refuse to have sex with their husbands and force them to get their spouses' permission before leaving the house, looking for a job, going to the doctor or receiving education. Gordon Brown has led the international condemnation of the law, saying today it would be unacceptable for British soldiers to die defending a regime that enacted oppressive legislation of this kind. The prime minister told Sky News that Nato leaders had attacked the law in the communique issued at the end of the summit in Strasbourg, and that Karzai had told him it would not come into force in the way that it had been reported. (....) +http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/apr/05/afghanistan-shia-rape-law-scrap "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." -Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
